articles.headline: Qaeda Video Vows Iraq Defeat for 'Crusader' U.S.
articles.snippet: Abu Musab al-Zarqawi praised the insurgents and denounced the efforts to form a new Iraqi government.
articles.abstract: Abu Musab al-Zarqawi praised the insurgents and denounced the efforts to form a new Iraqi government.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Wednesday, April 26 — A man identifying himself as Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the head of Al Qaeda in Iraq, appeared in a video released Tuesday calling the American effort here a "crusader" campaign and denouncing the efforts to form a new Iraqi government.

articles.headline: Abuse Charge Set for a U.S. Colonel
articles.snippet: Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan would be the highest-ranking officer to face charges tied to abuse at Abu Ghraib prison.
articles.abstract: Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan would be the highest-ranking officer to face charges tied to abuse at Abu Ghraib prison.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 25 — The Army plans to charge Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan, the former head of the interrogation center at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, with dereliction of duty, lying to investigators and conduct unbecoming an officer, Army officials and a lawyer for the officer said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: New Press Secretary Chosen
articles.snippet: Tony Snow, the Fox News commentator, has agreed to become the White House press secretary, administration officials said. Page A16.
articles.abstract: Tony Snow, the Fox News commentator, has agreed to become the White House press secretary, administration officials said. Page A16.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tony Snow, the Fox News commentator, has agreed to become the White House press secretary, administration officials said. Page A16.

articles.headline: What Price Loyalty? Something Free
articles.snippet: TOM PLASKETT was sitting on a flight from Boston to Dallas one day in 1980 with a problem that needed solving.     At 36 years old, Mr. Plaskett had just inherited the top marketing job at American Airlines from the famously intense Robert L. Cran...
articles.abstract: TOM PLASKETT was sitting on a flight from Boston to Dallas one day in 1980 with a problem that needed solving.     At 36 years old, Mr. Plaskett had just inherited the top marketing job at American Airlines from the famously intense Robert L. Crandall, who had become the company president. Mr. Crandall, like hundreds of other executives before and since, was looking for a way to keep customers loyal to his company.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOM PLASKETT was sitting on a flight from Boston to Dallas one day in 1980 with a problem that needed solving.

articles.headline: Abuse Charge Set for a U.S. Colonel
articles.snippet: The Army plans to charge Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan, the former head of the interrogation center at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, with dereliction of duty, lying to investigators and conduct unbecoming an officer, Army officials and a lawyer for the o...
articles.abstract: The Army plans to charge Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan, the former head of the interrogation center at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, with dereliction of duty, lying to investigators and conduct unbecoming an officer, Army officials and a lawyer for the officer said on Tuesday.      Colonel Jordan would be the highest-ranking officer at Abu Ghraib to face criminal charges in connection with the abuses at the prison. Ten low-ranking soldiers who served at the prison outside Baghdad have been convicted.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 25 - The Army plans to charge Lt. Col. Steven L. Jordan, the former head of the interrogation center at Abu Ghraib prison in Iraq, with dereliction of duty, lying to investigators and conduct unbecoming an officer, Army officials and a lawyer for the officer said on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Revenue Up at Amazon; Costs, Too
articles.snippet: Even as Amazon, the online retailer, reported another jump in its quarterly revenue, analysts continued to express concern yesterday about the company's ability to get its high costs under control.     The 20 percent increase in first-quarter reve...
articles.abstract: Even as Amazon, the online retailer, reported another jump in its quarterly revenue, analysts continued to express concern yesterday about the company's ability to get its high costs under control.     The 20 percent increase in first-quarter revenue and a 35 percent decline in earnings -- attributed largely to a change in the reporting of employee stock options -- mostly conformed to expectations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as Amazon, the online retailer, reported another jump in its quarterly revenue, analysts continued to express concern yesterday about the company's ability to get its high costs under control.

articles.headline: For Sun Microsystems, a Leader With Little Taste for Convention
articles.snippet: Jonathan I. Schwartz, the new chief executive of Sun Microsystems, likes to take visitors on whiteboard tours of what at first glance appear to be highly unorthodox business ideas.     General Motors, he suggests, should think about giving away it...
articles.abstract: Jonathan I. Schwartz, the new chief executive of Sun Microsystems, likes to take visitors on whiteboard tours of what at first glance appear to be highly unorthodox business ideas.     General Motors, he suggests, should think about giving away its cars to customers willing to subscribe to an aggressively priced version of OnStar, the company's cellular telephone-based support service -- the way cable companies give away set-top boxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 - Jonathan I. Schwartz, the new chief executive of Sun Microsystems, likes to take visitors on whiteboard tours of what at first glance appear to be highly unorthodox business ideas.

articles.headline: Russia, Rich in Wells, Aims to Buy Into the Retail Side of Oil and Gas
articles.snippet: Just a couple of years ago, Russia's big energy companies hardly ventured outside the former Soviet Union. These days, they are trying to horse-trade on a global scale, swapping stakes in their giant oil and gas fields for ports, pipelines and net...
articles.abstract: Just a couple of years ago, Russia's big energy companies hardly ventured outside the former Soviet Union. These days, they are trying to horse-trade on a global scale, swapping stakes in their giant oil and gas fields for ports, pipelines and networks of gas stations around the world.      Executives streaming in from China, Israel and India are lining up outside Gazprom's headquarters, hoping for a piece of Russia's natural gas reserves.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW, April 25 - Just a couple of years ago, Russia's big energy companies hardly ventured outside the former Soviet Union. These days, they are trying to horse-trade on a global scale, swapping stakes in their giant oil and gas fields for ports, pipelines and networks of gas stations around the world.

articles.headline: Qaeda Video Vows Iraq Defeat for 'Crusader' U.S.
articles.snippet: A man identifying himself as Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the head of Al Qaeda in Iraq, appeared in a video released Tuesday calling the American effort here a ''crusader'' campaign and denouncing the efforts to form a new Iraqi government.     The 34-mi...
articles.abstract: A man identifying himself as Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the head of Al Qaeda in Iraq, appeared in a video released Tuesday calling the American effort here a ''crusader'' campaign and denouncing the efforts to form a new Iraqi government.     The 34-minute video, posted on a Web site used by jihadist groups, shows a man who appears to be Mr. Zarqawi, speaking and gesturing, meeting with his lieutenants, and firing long bursts from an American machine gun in a stretch of empty desert. He has a mustache and a beard, wears black fatigues and a cap, and at one point identifies himself by name. He also refers to himself as ''the brains of Al Qaeda in Iraq.''
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, Wednesday, April 26 - A man identifying himself as Abu Musab al-Zarqawi, the head of Al Qaeda in Iraq, appeared in a video released Tuesday calling the American effort here a "crusader" campaign and denouncing the efforts to form a new Iraqi government.

articles.headline: Bush Takes Steps to Ease Increase in Energy Prices
articles.snippet: President Bush announced a series of short-term steps on Tuesday intended to ease the rise in energy prices, including a suspension of government purchases to refill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a relaxation of environmental rules for the form...
articles.abstract: President Bush announced a series of short-term steps on Tuesday intended to ease the rise in energy prices, including a suspension of government purchases to refill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a relaxation of environmental rules for the formulation of gasoline and investigations into possible price gouging and price fixing.     In addressing energy prices in a speech here, Mr. Bush joined a chorus of lawmakers who have been advocating populist-sounding initiatives to respond to surges in gasoline and crude oil prices and the threat they pose to Republicans in this fall's Congressional elections.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, April 25 - President Bush announced a series of short-term steps on Tuesday intended to ease the rise in energy prices, including a suspension of government purchases to refill the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, a relaxation of environmental rules for the formulation of gasoline and investigations into possible price gouging and price fixing.

articles.headline: Hoping for a Blockbuster
articles.snippet: When GlaxoSmithKline began talking to Roche three years ago about commercializing the prescription diet drug Xenical, the timing could not have been better for Steven L. Burton.      An executive with Glaxo's consumer heath care division, Mr. Burt...
articles.abstract: When GlaxoSmithKline began talking to Roche three years ago about commercializing the prescription diet drug Xenical, the timing could not have been better for Steven L. Burton.      An executive with Glaxo's consumer heath care division, Mr. Burton had been overweight for years, carrying 270 to 275 pounds on his 6-foot-1 frame. Those measurements put him well into the ''obese'' category, a condition shared by 30 percent of American adults. And his doctor had just issued a stern warning to Mr. Burton.
articles.lead_paragraph: When GlaxoSmithKline began talking to Roche three years ago about commercializing the prescription diet drug Xenical, the timing could not have been better for Steven L. Burton.
